Award.AwardTitle: Representations, modular forms and Galois groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
A quadratic equation is a polynomial equation of degree two.
A formula for solving quadratic equations was already known to Babylonians in 1800BC, and is familiar to just about everybody who has taken some mathematics classes.
On the other hand, a formula for solving cubic (degree three equations) was developed much later, in the 16th century, during contests between Italian mathematicians. Higher degree equations remained a mystery. A breakthrough came in 19th century when Galois, a French mathematician, introduced a new tool, a group of permutations of the set of roots of a polynomial equation. This object, now called Galois group, expresses the nature of the polynomial equation in subtle ways. In particular, it gives a criterion whether the equation can be solved in terms of radicals. Fast forward to 20th century. Due to efforts of hundreds of mathematicians, a classification of finite simple groups has been obtained. A natural question is which of these groups appear as Galois groups. In a couple of recent works, C. Khare, M. Larsen and G.
Savin have developed a method of constructing Galois groups using Langlands functoriality principles. Gordan Savin is continuing his work on this subject, as the main theme of this project.

The activities supported by this grant will include participation of post-docs, graduate students, domestic and international collaborators.
The broader impacts of proposed activities are expected to be similar to those resulting from the grant DMS-0551846.
They include, but are not limited to,
research opportunities for undergraduate students. One such activity, supported by the previous grant, is the work of G. Savin and R. Denomme (undergraduate from the Ohio State University) on primality testing using elliptic curves with complex multiplication. The problem of factoring of large numbers and related problem of verifying that a large number is a prime number (primality testing) has attracted considerable attention in recent years due to applications in cryptography. Indeed, internet security is based on an observation that it is very easy to multiply numbers, but very hard to factor them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary object of this research was groups as they appear in number theory and geometry. Although the mathematical notion of a group is probably not familiar to most people, it is easy to illustrate the idea behind. Historically, mathematical groups went by a somewhat longer name, the groups of transformations, since examples arise from symmetries of various solids. For example, the group of symmetries of a regular tetrahedron contains 12 rotations, that is, rotations that preserve the tetrahedron. For example, one can rotate the tetrahedron aroud every vertex by a 120 degrees rotation. Similalry, one can look at a tilling of a plane by 60-60-60 degree triangles and the correspondig group of symmetries consits of all translations and rotatations of the plane that preserve the tiling. Even more exciting example is given by the attached picture of a disc (a model of the hyperbolic plane) tilled by 90-60-90-60-degree quarilaterals. Groups arise in a variety of ways, but it is useful to exhibit them, if possible, as groups of symmetries of a geometric object, such as a tilling. Then one can say a bit more about the structure of the group, as we shall explain. 

Note that, given two symmetries of a tilling, one can compose them and, in this way, obtain a new symmetry. A basic problem, in the theory of groups, is to find a generating set, i.e. a set of symmetries such that any symmetry is obtained by composing symmetries from the generating set. A tilling gives us a quick answer to this question. In the picured example the whole group of symmetries of the tiling is generated by only 4 symmetries: 4 reflections about the 4 lines cutting out any 90-60-90-60 quadrilateral. In one of the results of this research, a joint work with Mladen Bestivina, we have realized groups in a certain family (so called Fuchsian grousp) as groups of symmetries of tilings of the hyperbolic plane. In particular, each of those groups (infinitely many) has its own beautiful tiling, and the tiling can be used to find a generting set of the group. 

Another way of studying groups is by means of representing group elements by square matrices. In this way composing of symmetries corresponds to multiplying matrices. This point of view gives rise to the subject of representation theory in mathematics. The main problems in this subject are perhaps not so easy to explain to the general public, perhaps it suffices to say that the central problems in the subject are related to the phenomena that different groups can have very related representation theories. In several joint papers with Wee Teck Gan, a key progress on so called theta correspondences of representations has been obtained. 

In addition to the research outcame, this project has supported several graduate students. Two of them (both US citizens) have succesfully completed a PhD degree and are working, one for the Air Force, the other at the University of Missouri, Columbia.
